review.title: Belief Revision in Structured Probabilistic Argumentation
review.abstract: In real-world applications, knowledge bases consisting of all the information at hand for a specific domain, along with the current state of affairs, are bound to contain contradictory data coming from different sources, as well as data with varying degrees of uncertainty attached. Likewise, an important aspect of the effort associated with maintaining knowledge bases is deciding what information is no longer useful; pieces of information (such as intelligence reports) may be outdated, may come from sources that have recently been discovered to be of low quality, or abundant evidence may be available that contradicts them. In this paper, we propose a probabilistic structured argumentation framework that arises from the extension of Presumptive Defeasible Logic Programming (PreDeLP) with probabilistic models, and argue that this formalism is capable of addressing the basic issues of handling contradictory and uncertain data. Then, to address the last issue, we focus on the study of non-prioritized belief revision operations over probabilistic PreDeLP programs. We propose a set of rationality postulates -- based on well-known ones developed for classical knowledge bases -- that characterize how such operations should behave, and study a class of operators along with theoretical relationships with the proposed postulates, including a representation theorem stating the equivalence between this class and the class of operators characterized by the postulates.

sections.text: Unlike EM, which describes probabilistic information about the state of the real world, AM must allow competing ideas, so it must be able to present conflicting information; the algorithmic approach that we will describe later allows arguments to be constructed on the basis of AM that can "compete" with each other to answer a given query; in this contest - known as the dialectical process - one argument can defeat another on the basis of a comparison criterion that determines the prevailing reasoning; as a result of this process, certain arguments are justified (those that are not surpassed by other arguments), providing an appropriate explanation for the response to a given query; the transparency that the system provides can allow knowledge engineers to identify potentially false input information and refine the models or alternatively gather more information; in short, argument-based reasoning has been examined as a natural way to manage this information (which we initially consider to be a way for structuring it).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have proposed an extension of the PreDeLP language that makes it possible to comment on sentences with probable events; such events are linked to a probable model that allows a clear separation of interests between secure and uncertain knowledge. After the presentation of the language, we focused on the characterization of verification operations against P-PreDeLP KBs. We presented a series of postulates inspired by those submitted for an unprioritized revision of classical beliefs, and then studied a construction based on these postulates, proving that the two characteristics are equivalent. As future work, we plan to investigate other types of operators, such as more general ones that allow modification of EM, as well as others that operate at different levels of granularity. Finally, we will examine the application of PPreDeLP to real-world problems in cybersecurity and cyberwarfare.
